security: This report contains details regarding communications between Indonesian officials concerning Castro's reaction to the JFK assassination. Disclosing such information could reveal intelligence-gathering methods and sources, potentially harming international relations and compromising future intelligence efforts. Directly quoting: 'FR Havana: INDONESIA 24 Nov 63 TO Djakarta: DEPARLU'.
summary: This document is a report summarizing Fidel Castro's televised speech responding to accusations in the U.S. press that Lee Harvey Oswald was a pro-Castro communist; Castro denied any Cuban involvement or benefit from Kennedy's assassination and criticized ultra-reactionary groups in the U.S.
summary_one_paragraph: Originating from Havana on November 24, 1963, this top-secret report relays Indonesian intelligence regarding Fidel Castro's televised response to accusations linking Lee Harvey Oswald to Cuba. Addressing claims that Oswald was a pro-Castro communist, Castro denied any Cuban involvement in President Kennedy's assassination, expressing remorse and asserting that Cuba gained no advantage from the event. He attributed the accusations to ultra-reactionary groups within the U.S. seeking to discredit Cuba and the Soviet Union, further suggesting that President Johnson would be less effective than Kennedy in curbing these groups' influence.
title: Report on Castro's Television Speech Regarding President Kennedy's Assassination
